Trans 24.11.93. To proof.
full citation.
Tovale
I have to acknowledge yours of the 5th & to thank you for so promptly attending to Mr Clarke's wishes.

As regards the great Cranbourne Meteorite, I regret that the claims of the British Museum and of that of Melbourne to its [...] should clash, but if the question be referred for my decision by Dr Mueller and yourself, I can only give, as you suggest, the judgement of Solomon and decree that it shall be sawn asunder, with very little hope that this appeal to your feelings will lead to relenting on either side.

I must explain however with regard to the course I have taken in the matter, that when Dr Mueller called on me the other day with a letter which he had received for Professor Maskelyne asking for his aid to secure the Meteorite for the British Museum, that I had not the smallest idea that it was contemplated to retain it in the colony; and though I promised therefore as he desired to speak to my advisers about it before it was finally sent away, I suggested that he shld not wait for that, lest Mr Abel or somebody else shd get possession of it, and offered to guarantee the expense of getting it home out of my own pocket.

The fact was indeed that a year ago — not very long after Mr Fitzgibbon had at my instruction (in consequence of my accidentally seeing [...] at the Town Hall a portion of the smaller meteor) brought the subject of these meteors before the Royal Society, I hd made an attempt to get one or other of them for the Government here, [...] that Dr Mueller to whom the subject was mentioned would persuade his colleagues to authorise the necessary expenditure. But my enquiries were last September brought to a conclusion by learning from Mr FitzGibbon that Mr Abel would only sell the small one on very high terms, and that Mr Bruce
James Bruce. to whom the large mass belonged, had stated positively that he had brought it expressly to present to the British Museum .
of obtaining it, it struck me that it was [...] [...] therefore to afford them every aid.

I still think that it is of more importance to Science at large that it shld be placed in the British Museum as one of a complete series, than kept here, wholly or in part, where it will be an isolated specimen —, and [...] others; but I quite admit that it is your duty in the position you occupy — as you have persuaded Mr Bruce to divide it — to secure the half for the Melbourne Museum and I believe the arrangements you propose as to the division to be the best that can be devised. I hope that you will be able to get the sanction of the Government to the necessary outlay at once, as I doubt that there should be any further delay in the settlement of the matter.
I enclose a letter just received from Mr Clarke, & thanking you for your kind enquiries as to my family,
